snippet: Requiring prospective New York State lawyers to perform 50 hours of pro bono services before they are approved to practice law is a worthy step in the right direction.
abstract: Editorial commends change in New York State's bar admissions process that will require prospective lawyers to perform 50 hours of pro bono services before they are approved to practice law; offers requirement will not only allow more low-income New Yorkers to receive free legal help, but also help foster a stronger culture of public service in the legal profession.
lead_paragraph: Requiring prospective New York State lawyers to perform 50 hours of pro bono services before they are approved to practice law is a worthy step in the right direction.
